segment.source: Windows apps concept mapping for Android and iOS developers
segment.target: Windows apps concept mapping for Android and iOS developers

segment.source: If you're a developer with Android or iOS skills and/or code, and you want to make the move to Windows 10 and the Universal Windows Platform (UWP), then this resource has all you need to map platform features—and your knowledge—between the three platforms.
segment.target: If you're a developer with Android or iOS skills and/or code, and you want to make the move to Windows 10 and the Universal Windows Platform (UWP), then this resource has all you need to map platform features—and your knowledge—between the three platforms.

segment.source: Also see the porting content in Move from iOS to UWP.
segment.target: Also see the porting content in Move from iOS to UWP.

segment.source: Design language.
segment.target: Design language.

segment.source: A set of conventions that prescribe how apps on the platform should look and behave.
segment.target: A set of conventions that prescribe how apps on the platform should look and behave.

segment.source: Android Material Design guidelines provide a visual language for Android designers and developers to follow.
segment.target: Android Material Design guidelines provide a visual language for Android designers and developers to follow.

segment.source: Human Interface Guidelines provide advice for iOS designers and developers.
segment.target: Human Interface Guidelines provide advice for iOS designers and developers.

segment.source: UWP Windows Apps Design shows you how to create an app that looks fantastic on all Windows 10 devices.
segment.target: UWP Windows Apps Design shows you how to create an app that looks fantastic on all Windows 10 devices.

segment.source: You will find user-interface (UI) design fundamentals, responsive design techniques, and a full list of detailed guidelines.
segment.target: You will find user-interface (UI) design fundamentals, responsive design techniques, and a full list of detailed guidelines.

segment.source: User interface markup language.
segment.target: User interface markup language.

segment.source: A markup language that renders and describes a UI and its components.
segment.target: A markup language that renders and describes a UI and its components.

segment.source: Each platform provides an editor for both visual and markup editing.
segment.target: Each platform provides an editor for both visual and markup editing.

segment.source: XML layouts, edited using Android Studio or Eclipse.
segment.target: XML layouts, edited using Android Studio or Eclipse.

segment.source: XIB and Storyboards edited using Interface Builder inside Xcode.
segment.target: XIB and Storyboards edited using Interface Builder inside Xcode.

segment.source: XAML, edited using Microsoft Visual Studio and Blend for Visual Studio.
segment.target: XAML, edited using Microsoft Visual Studio and Blend for Visual Studio.

segment.source: Built-in user interface controls.
segment.target: Built-in user interface controls.

segment.source: Reusable UI elements provided by the platform such as buttons, list controls, and text controls.
segment.target: Reusable UI elements provided by the platform such as buttons, list controls, and text controls.

segment.source: Prebuilt view and view group classes referred to as widgets, layouts, text fields, containers, date/time controls and expert controls.
segment.target: Prebuilt view and view group classes referred to as widgets, layouts, text fields, containers, date/time controls and expert controls.

segment.source: Views and controls found in the Xcode object library and listed in the UIKit user interface catalog.
segment.target: Views and controls found in the Xcode object library and listed in the UIKit user interface catalog.

segment.source: Views include image views, picker views and scroll views.
segment.target: Views include image views, picker views and scroll views.

segment.source: Controls include buttons, date pickers and text fields.
segment.target: Controls include buttons, date pickers and text fields.

segment.source: The XAML platform provides you with a generous set of built-in controls such as buttons, list controls, panels, text controls, command bars, pickers, media, and inking.
segment.target: The XAML platform provides you with a generous set of built-in controls such as buttons, list controls, panels, text controls, command bars, pickers, media, and inking.

segment.source: Control event-handling.
segment.target: Control event-handling.

segment.source: Defining the logic that runs when events are triggered within UI controls.
segment.target: Defining the logic that runs when events are triggered within UI controls.

segment.source: Event handlers and event listeners are added in XML or programmatically.
segment.target: Event handlers and event listeners are added in XML or programmatically.

segment.source: Controls send action messages to targets.
segment.target: Controls send action messages to targets.

segment.source: You can define methods to handle the events of a XAML control in a code-behind file attached to the XAML page.
segment.target: You can define methods to handle the events of a XAML control in a code-behind file attached to the XAML page.

segment.source: Event handlers are always written in code.
segment.target: Event handlers are always written in code.

segment.source: But you can hook those handlers to events either in XAML markup or in code.
segment.target: But you can hook those handlers to events either in XAML markup or in code.

segment.source: Data binding.
segment.target: Data binding.

segment.source: A software design pattern that allows your app UI to render data and optionally stay in sync with that data.
segment.target: A software design pattern that allows your app UI to render data and optionally stay in sync with that data.

segment.source: There is a Data Binding Library provided, although it is still in beta.
segment.target: There is a Data Binding Library provided, although it is still in beta.

segment.source: No built-in bindings system exists on iOS.
segment.target: No built-in bindings system exists on iOS.

segment.source: Key-value observing can be built upon to perform data binding, either with the use of a third-party library, or writing additional code.
segment.target: Key-value observing can be built upon to perform data binding, either with the use of a third-party library, or writing additional code.

segment.source: Controls use a delegate/callback approach for obtaining data.
segment.target: Controls use a delegate/callback approach for obtaining data.

segment.source: The UWP platform handles data binding for you.
segment.target: The UWP platform handles data binding for you.

segment.source: You use the {x:Bind} markup extension to take advantage of high performance binding or {Binding} to take advantage of more features.
segment.target: You use the {x:Bind} markup extension to take advantage of high performance binding or {Binding} to take advantage of more features.

segment.source: It’s then just a case of configuring your binding to choose whether the platform uses one-way binding to display values from a data source in your UI, or whether it also observes those values and updates your UI when they change with two-way binding.
segment.target: It’s then just a case of configuring your binding to choose whether the platform uses one-way binding to display values from a data source in your UI, or whether it also observes those values and updates your UI when they change with two-way binding.

segment.source: Data Binding
segment.target: Data Binding

segment.source: UI Automation.
segment.target: UI Automation.

segment.source: Programmatic access to UI elements, making apps accessible to assistive technology products and enabling automated test scripts to interact with your UI.
segment.target: Programmatic access to UI elements, making apps accessible to assistive technology products and enabling automated test scripts to interact with your UI.

segment.source: Text labels, contentDescription and hint values help ensure UI elements can be found by automation.
segment.target: Text labels, contentDescription and hint values help ensure UI elements can be found by automation.

segment.source: Android Studio allows you to write UI tests using the UI Automator and Espresso testing frameworks.
segment.target: Android Studio allows you to write UI tests using the UI Automator and Espresso testing frameworks.

segment.source: The Automation instrument allows you to write automated UI test scripts which identify elements using the accessibility settings or the element's position in the element hierarchy.
segment.target: The Automation instrument allows you to write automated UI test scripts which identify elements using the accessibility settings or the element's position in the element hierarchy.

segment.source: You get programmatic access to built-in UI elements in UWP out-of-box with UI Automation.
segment.target: You get programmatic access to built-in UI elements in UWP out-of-box with UI Automation.

segment.source: Custom Automation Peers allow you to provide automation support for your own custom UI classes.
segment.target: Custom Automation Peers allow you to provide automation support for your own custom UI classes.

segment.source: The Coded UI Test Project in Visual Studio allows you to automatically test your whole application through the UI, or to test the UI in isolation.
segment.target: The Coded UI Test Project in Visual Studio allows you to automatically test your whole application through the UI, or to test the UI in isolation.

segment.source: Changing the appearance of a control.
segment.target: Changing the appearance of a control.

segment.source: Editing size, color and other attributes.
segment.target: Editing size, color and other attributes.

segment.source: Controls have properties which can be edited using the designer tool, in XML markup or programmatically.
segment.target: Controls have properties which can be edited using the designer tool, in XML markup or programmatically.

segment.source: Controls have attributes which you can edit using the Attributes Inspector in Interface Builder or programmatically.
segment.target: Controls have attributes which you can edit using the Attributes Inspector in Interface Builder or programmatically.

segment.source: You can edit the properties of controls in the XAML markup or programmatically, using Visual Studio and Blend for Visual Studio.
segment.target: You can edit the properties of controls in the XAML markup or programmatically, using Visual Studio and Blend for Visual Studio.

segment.source: Add controls and handle events
segment.target: Add controls and handle events

segment.source: Reusable visual styles.
segment.target: Reusable visual styles.

segment.source: Apply visual changes to a number of controls, in a reusable format.
segment.target: Apply visual changes to a number of controls, in a reusable format.

segment.source: XML styles are sets of properties that are applied to one or more controls.
segment.target: XML styles are sets of properties that are applied to one or more controls.

segment.source: iOS does not support reusable visual styles out-of-box, but the UIAppearance protocol allows multiple controls to share common attributes.
segment.target: iOS does not support reusable visual styles out-of-box, but the UIAppearance protocol allows multiple controls to share common attributes.

segment.source: You can create reusable styles, which can be applied to multiple controls and stored in a ResourceDictionary for easy reuse.
segment.target: You can create reusable styles, which can be applied to multiple controls and stored in a ResourceDictionary for easy reuse.

segment.source: Quickstart: Styling Controls
segment.target: Quickstart: Styling Controls

segment.source: Editing the visual structure of controls.
segment.target: Editing the visual structure of controls.

segment.source: Customize the visual structure of a control beyond just modifying properties or attributes, e.g. moving the checkbox text underneath the checkbox.
segment.target: Customize the visual structure of a control beyond just modifying properties or attributes, e.g. moving the checkbox text underneath the checkbox.

segment.source: No simple method of editing the visual structure of controls exists in Android.
segment.target: No simple method of editing the visual structure of controls exists in Android.

segment.source: No simple method of editing the visual structure of controls exists in iOS.
segment.target: No simple method of editing the visual structure of controls exists in iOS.

segment.source: To customize the visual structure of a control, you can copy and edit its control template in XAML markup.
segment.target: To customize the visual structure of a control, you can copy and edit its control template in XAML markup.

segment.source: Quickstart: Control Templates
segment.target: Quickstart: Control Templates

segment.source: Built-in touch gestures.
segment.target: Built-in touch gestures.

segment.source: Provide customized touch support by handling high level abstracted gesture events such as tap and double tap in views and controls.
segment.target: Provide customized touch support by handling high level abstracted gesture events such as tap and double tap in views and controls.

segment.source: Gesture detectors detect common touch gestures including scrolling, long-press, tap, double-tap and fling.
segment.target: Gesture detectors detect common touch gestures including scrolling, long-press, tap, double-tap and fling.

segment.source: UIKit framework provides built-in gesture recognizers which detect touch gestures including tap, pinch, pan, swipe, rotate and long-press.
segment.target: UIKit framework provides built-in gesture recognizers which detect touch gestures including tap, pinch, pan, swipe, rotate and long-press.

segment.source: UI elements allow you to handle static gesture events including tap, double-tap, right-tap and holding, as well as manipulation gesture events including slide, swipe, turn, pinch and stretch.
segment.target: UI elements allow you to handle static gesture events including tap, double-tap, right-tap and holding, as well as manipulation gesture events including slide, swipe, turn, pinch and stretch.

segment.source: Gesture events are routed events and can be handled by parent objects containing the child UIElement.
segment.target: Gesture events are routed events and can be handled by parent objects containing the child UIElement.

segment.source: The layout defines the structure of the user interface.

segment.target: Layout is composed of view groups such as the LinearLayout and the RelativeLayout which can nest other view groups or views.

segment.target: Layout is composed of a UIViewController containing UIView's which can be nested.

segment.target: Presenting the user with methods of navigating between pages of equal hierarchical importance.

segment.source: Tabs, swipe views and navigation drawers provide lateral navigation.
segment.target: Tabs, swipe views and navigation drawers provide lateral navigation.

segment.source: Tab bar controllers, split view controllers and page view controllers allow navigation between views of equal hierarchy.
segment.target: Tab bar controllers, split view controllers and page view controllers allow navigation between views of equal hierarchy.

segment.source: You can display a persistent list of links/tabs above the content using tabs/pivots.
segment.target: You can display a persistent list of links/tabs above the content using tabs/pivots.

segment.source: The navigation pane/split view lets you display a list of links alongside the content.
segment.target: The navigation pane/split view lets you display a list of links alongside the content.

segment.target: Lists, and grid lists, buttons and other controls provide descendent navigation when used with intents to load other activities.

segment.source: Navigation controllers allow users to navigate between levels of a hierarchy.
segment.target: Navigation controllers allow users to navigate between levels of a hierarchy.

segment.source: Hubs let you show the user a preview of content which can be selected to navigate to child pages.
segment.target: Hubs let you show the user a preview of content which can be selected to navigate to child pages.

segment.source: Master/details let users pick from a list of item summaries which display next to the corresponding detail section.

segment.source: The back and up buttons inside the action bar provide ancestral and temporal navigation using the back stack.
segment.target: The back and up buttons inside the action bar provide ancestral and temporal navigation using the back stack.

segment.source: The navigation controller can have a back button added to it.
segment.target: The navigation controller can have a back button added to it.

segment.source: You can handle software or hardware back button presses easily using the back stack property which allows your users to traverse the navigation history.
segment.target: You can handle software or hardware back button presses easily using the back stack property which allows your users to traverse the navigation history.

segment.source: Splash screens are not provided by default, and are implemented by editing the first activities theme background.
segment.target: Splash screens are not provided by default, and are implemented by editing the first activities theme background.

segment.source: Apps must either have a static launch image or XIB/storyboard launch file.
segment.target: Apps must either have a static launch image or XIB/storyboard launch file.

segment.source: You create a splash screen using an image and colored background.
segment.target: You create a splash screen using an image and colored background.

segment.source: Splash screen time can be extended.

segment.source: Speech recognition for speech input, and additional voice capabilities.
segment.target: Speech recognition for speech input, and additional voice capabilities.

segment.source: Speech input can be provided by any app which implements a RecognizerIntent, such as Google Voice Search.
segment.target: Speech input can be provided by any app which implements a RecognizerIntent, such as Google Voice Search.

segment.source: The SpeechRecognizer class allows apps to use Google's speech recognition API.
segment.target: The SpeechRecognizer class allows apps to use Google's speech recognition API.

segment.source: No built-in speech recognition or speech input APIs exist.
segment.target: No built-in speech recognition or speech input APIs exist.

segment.source: You can use the speech recognition API to interact with your app in the foreground.
segment.target: You can use the speech recognition API to interact with your app in the foreground.

segment.source: You can use speech-based Cortana interactions to launch apps in the foreground or background, and to interact with background apps.
segment.target: You can use speech-based Cortana interactions to launch apps in the foreground or background, and to interact with background apps.

segment.source: Handling keyboard, mouse, stylus and other inputs.
segment.target: Handling keyboard, mouse, stylus and other inputs.

segment.source: Support for interactions includes touch, touchpad, stylus, mouse and keyboard.
segment.target: Support for interactions includes touch, touchpad, stylus, mouse and keyboard.

segment.source: Movements and inputs are reported in the same way as touch, but it is possible to detect more information about the input device.
segment.target: Movements and inputs are reported in the same way as touch, but it is possible to detect more information about the input device.

segment.source: Support for touch, the Apple Pencil and hardware keyboards are provided.
segment.target: Support for touch, the Apple Pencil and hardware keyboards are provided.

segment.source: You will find support for a wide range of interactions including touch, touchpad, pen/stylus with digital ink, mouse and keyboard.
segment.target: You will find support for a wide range of interactions including touch, touchpad, pen/stylus with digital ink, mouse and keyboard.

segment.source: Your apps can handle the data without needing to know which input device was used, and raw input device data can be accessed if needed.

segment.source: Local app data.
segment.target: Local app data.

segment.source: Storing settings and files related to your app locally.
segment.target: Storing settings and files related to your app locally.

segment.source: Local files can be saved using openFileOutput and openFileInput.
segment.target: Local files can be saved using openFileOutput and openFileInput.

segment.source: Settings in a shared preferences file can be accessed using getSharedPreferences.
segment.target: Settings in a shared preferences file can be accessed using getSharedPreferences.

segment.source: Local files can be stored in the application support directory, accessed via the NSFileManager class.
segment.target: Local files can be stored in the application support directory, accessed via the NSFileManager class.

segment.source: Settings in preferences files can be accessed by the NSUserDefaults class.
segment.target: Settings in preferences files can be accessed by the NSUserDefaults class.

segment.source: The Windows.Storage classes handle local data storage for you in a unified way.
segment.target: The Windows.Storage classes handle local data storage for you in a unified way.

segment.source: You store settings as an ApplicationDataContainer object, accessed via the ApplicationData.LocalSettings property.
segment.target: You store settings as an ApplicationDataContainer object, accessed via the ApplicationData.LocalSettings property.

segment.source: You store files in a StorageFolder object accessed via the ApplicationData.LocalFolder property.
segment.target: You store files in a StorageFolder object accessed via the ApplicationData.LocalFolder property.

segment.source: Store and retrieve settings and other app data
segment.target: Store and retrieve settings and other app data

segment.source: Local database storage.
segment.target: Local database storage.

segment.source: Storing app data in a relational database, with object-relational mappers (ORM) if applicable.
segment.target: Storing app data in a relational database, with object-relational mappers (ORM) if applicable.

segment.source: The SQLite database is provided.
segment.target: The SQLite database is provided.

segment.source: No ORM is built-in.
segment.target: No ORM is built-in.

segment.source: SQL queries are run using the SQLiteDatabase class.
segment.target: SQL queries are run using the SQLiteDatabase class.

segment.source: The SQLite database is provided.
segment.target: The SQLite database is provided.

segment.source: CoreData is the built-in object graph framework which can be used with SQLite and provide functionality comparable with an ORM.
segment.target: CoreData is the built-in object graph framework which can be used with SQLite and provide functionality comparable with an ORM.

segment.source: You can store data using SQLite.
segment.target: You can store data using SQLite.

segment.source: Entity Framework is a built-in ORM which eliminates the need to write lots of data access code and enables you to easily query the database without writing SQL.
segment.target: Entity Framework is a built-in ORM which eliminates the need to write lots of data access code and enables you to easily query the database without writing SQL.

segment.source: You can run SQL queries directly with the SQLite library.
segment.target: You can run SQL queries directly with the SQLite library.

segment.source: Built-in libraries that let you communicate with web services and web servers using HTTP(S).
segment.target: Built-in libraries that let you communicate with web services and web servers using HTTP(S).

segment.source: HTTP libraries HttpURLConnection and Volley.

segment.source: NSURLSession, NSURLConnection and NSURLDownload.
segment.target: NSURLSession, NSURLConnection and NSURLDownload.

segment.source: Cloud backup services.
segment.target: Cloud backup services.

segment.source: Platform-provided backup services for app data.
segment.target: Platform-provided backup services for app data.

segment.source: Android's backup manager handles the backing up of application data in Google's Android Backup Service.
segment.target: Android's backup manager handles the backing up of application data in Google's Android Backup Service.

segment.source: iCloud Backup can be configured by a user to handle their backups, including app data.
segment.target: iCloud Backup can be configured by a user to handle their backups, including app data.

segment.source: Apps which use iCloud compatible Core Data, the iCloud key-value store and iCloud document storage.
segment.target: Apps which use iCloud compatible Core Data, the iCloud key-value store and iCloud document storage.

segment.source: Any app data that you store using the roaming ApplicationData APIs (including RoamingFolder and RoamingSettings) will be automatically synced to the cloud and to the user’s other devices, too.
segment.target: Any app data that you store using the roaming ApplicationData APIs (including RoamingFolder and RoamingSettings) will be automatically synced to the cloud and to the user’s other devices, too.

segment.target: Downloading large and small files over HTTP.

segment.target: URLConnection and HTTPURLConnection are used to download over HTTP and FTP, it is also possible to make use of the system download manager to download in the background.

segment.source: The background transfer API lets you reliably transfer files over HTTP(S) and FTP, taking into account app suspension, connectivity loss and adjusting based on connectivity and battery life.

segment.source: View optimization for a responsive UI.
segment.target: View optimization for a responsive UI.

segment.source: Improving performance by optimizing views.
segment.target: Improving performance by optimizing views.

segment.source: Optimizing layout hierarchies using the Hierarchy Viewer tool, reusing layouts and loading views on demand are all techniques to help keep the UI thread responsive and avoid "Application Not Responding" dialogs (ANR's).
segment.target: Optimizing layout hierarchies using the Hierarchy Viewer tool, reusing layouts and loading views on demand are all techniques to help keep the UI thread responsive and avoid "Application Not Responding" dialogs (ANR's).

segment.source: Fixing UI issues with offscreen rendering, blended layers, rasterization using the Core Animation tool help keep the UI thread responsive.
segment.target: Fixing UI issues with offscreen rendering, blended layers, rasterization using the Core Animation tool help keep the UI thread responsive.

segment.source: You can easily optimize XAML markup and layouts by following a few simple steps.
segment.target: You can easily optimize XAML markup and layouts by following a few simple steps.

segment.source: Techniques include reducing layout structure, minimizing the element count and minimizing overdrawing.
segment.target: Techniques include reducing layout structure, minimizing the element count and minimizing overdrawing.

segment.source: Use of threading to maintain a responsive UI and run multiple tasks in parallel.
segment.target: Use of threading to maintain a responsive UI and run multiple tasks in parallel.

segment.target: Threading is achieved using the classes Runnable, Handler, ThreadPoolExecutor, and the higher level AsyncTask.

segment.target: Threading is achieved using NSThread, Grand Central Dispatch, and the higher level NSOperation.

segment.target: Avoid threading complexity by taking advantage of asynchronous programming patterns to keep the UI thread responsive.

segment.target: The use of threading is required to create your own asynchronous classes.

segment.source: Platform features that allow users to make purchases in your apps.
segment.target: Platform features that allow users to make purchases in your apps.

segment.source: In-app billing is provided by Google Services.
segment.target: In-app billing is provided by Google Services.

segment.source: Products are added to the Google Play Developer Console.
segment.target: Products are added to the Google Play Developer Console.

segment.source: In-app purchases are implemented with the Google Play Billing Library.
segment.target: In-app purchases are implemented with the Google Play Billing Library.

segment.source: Products are added to iTunes Connect.
segment.target: Products are added to iTunes Connect.

segment.source: In-app purchases are implemented using the StoreKit framework.
segment.target: In-app purchases are implemented using the StoreKit framework.

segment.source: Products are purchased using SKMutablePayment and SKPaymentQueue.
segment.target: Products are purchased using SKMutablePayment and SKPaymentQueue.

segment.source: You create in-app product purchases for your app by adding them to your app and submitting them to the Store.
segment.target: You create in-app product purchases for your app by adding them to your app and submitting them to the Store.

segment.source: You use the CurrentApp class to define in-app purchases.
segment.target: You use the CurrentApp class to define in-app purchases.

segment.source: You use CurrentApp.RequestProductPurchaseAsync to display the UI that allows customers to purchase the product.
segment.target: You use CurrentApp.RequestProductPurchaseAsync to display the UI that allows customers to purchase the product.

segment.source: Consumable in-app purchases.
segment.target: Consumable in-app purchases.

segment.source: In-app products which can be purchased, used and then purchased again.
segment.target: In-app products which can be purchased, used and then purchased again.

segment.source: Consumable purchases are enabled by making a regular purchase and then consuming it with consumePurchase, enabling it to be purchased, used, and then purchased again.
segment.target: Consumable purchases are enabled by making a regular purchase and then consuming it with consumePurchase, enabling it to be purchased, used, and then purchased again.

segment.source: Consumable products are defined as consumable products in iTunes Connect.
segment.target: Consumable products are defined as consumable products in iTunes Connect.

segment.source: You can support consumables by defining their product type as Consumable when you submit them to the Store.
segment.target: You can support consumables by defining their product type as Consumable when you submit them to the Store.

segment.source: You then call CurrentApp.ReportConsumableFulfillmentAsync after a consumable purchase has been made to allow the customer to access it.
segment.target: You then call CurrentApp.ReportConsumableFulfillmentAsync after a consumable purchase has been made to allow the customer to access it.

segment.target: Enable consumable in-app purchases

segment.target: Enabling you to test your in-app purchase code without putting your app in the Store.

segment.source: The in-app billing sandbox is used for testing.
segment.target: The in-app billing sandbox is used for testing.

segment.source: Sandbox tester accounts are used for testing.
segment.target: Sandbox tester accounts are used for testing.

segment.source: You can test in-app purchases by simply using the CurrentAppSimulator class in place of CurrentApp.
segment.target: You can test in-app purchases by simply using the CurrentAppSimulator class in place of CurrentApp.

segment.source: Trials.
segment.target: Trials.

segment.source: Enabling you to easily limit content or remove advertising based on a trial version of an app.
segment.target: Enabling you to easily limit content or remove advertising based on a trial version of an app.

segment.source: Google Play doesn't officially support app trials.
segment.target: Google Play doesn't officially support app trials.

segment.source: Trials or removing advertising is achieved by creating an in-app purchase and taking the appropriate code path when confirming the purchase was successful.
segment.target: Trials or removing advertising is achieved by creating an in-app purchase and taking the appropriate code path when confirming the purchase was successful.

segment.source: The App Store doesn't officially support app trials.
segment.target: The App Store doesn't officially support app trials.

segment.source: Trials or removing advertising is achieved by creating an in-app purchase and taking the appropriate code path when confirming the purchase was successful.
segment.target: Trials or removing advertising is achieved by creating an in-app purchase and taking the appropriate code path when confirming the purchase was successful.

segment.source: You can offer a free trial version of your app by using the 'Free Trial' option when submitting your app to the Store.
segment.target: You can offer a free trial version of your app by using the 'Free Trial' option when submitting your app to the Store.

segment.source: You can then use LicenseInformation.IsTrial to check the trial status of the app and present different code paths accordingly.
segment.target: You can then use LicenseInformation.IsTrial to check the trial status of the app and present different code paths accordingly.

segment.source: You can register for the LicenseChanged event to be notified when the user changes the trial status while the app is running.
segment.target: You can register for the LicenseChanged event to be notified when the user changes the trial status while the app is running.

segment.target: Testing for device features at runtime using PackageManager.hasSystemFeature enables you to decide if hardware specific code can run.

segment.source: Notifications and actions are defined using a NotificationCompat.Builder and can be scheduled and handled in-app using AlarmManager and BroadcastReceiver.
segment.target: Notifications and actions are defined using a NotificationCompat.Builder and can be scheduled and handled in-app using AlarmManager and BroadcastReceiver.

segment.source: Local notifications are created using UILocalNotification, and can be scheduled with UILocalNotification.scheduleLocalNotification:.

segment.source: You can schedule a toast notification using ScheduledToastNotification.
segment.target: You can schedule a toast notification using ScheduledToastNotification.

segment.source: You can send a tile notification from your app using the TileNotification class, or schedule a tile notification with ScheduledTileNotification.

segment.source: A notification sent from a push notification server and optionally handled in-app.

segment.source: Google Cloud Messaging provides push notification support for Android.

segment.source: Remote or push notifications are provided by the Apple Push Notification service (APNs).

segment.source: Capturing media.
segment.target: Capturing media.

segment.source: Recording audio and visual content.
segment.target: Recording audio and visual content.

segment.source: Using an intent such as MediaStore.ACTION_VIDEO_CAPTURE allows media to be captured with an existing camera app.
segment.target: Using an intent such as MediaStore.ACTION_VIDEO_CAPTURE allows media to be captured with an existing camera app.

segment.source: Using the android.hardware.camera2 or camera library enables the implementation of a custom camera interface.
segment.target: Using the android.hardware.camera2 or camera library enables the implementation of a custom camera interface.

segment.source: MediaRecorder APIs can be used to capture audio.
segment.target: MediaRecorder APIs can be used to capture audio.

segment.source: The UIImagePickerController allows for the capture of video and photos with the system UI.
segment.target: The UIImagePickerController allows for the capture of video and photos with the system UI.

segment.source: The AVFoundation classes such as AVCaptureSession enable direct access to the camera.
segment.target: The AVFoundation classes such as AVCaptureSession enable direct access to the camera.

segment.source: The AVAudioRecorder class enables audio recording.
segment.target: The AVAudioRecorder class enables audio recording.

segment.source: You can capture photos and video while using the built-in camera UI with the CameraCaptureUI class.
segment.target: You can capture photos and video while using the built-in camera UI with the CameraCaptureUI class.

segment.source: You can interact with the camera at a low level, and capture audio with classes in Windows.Media.Capture such as the MediaCapture API.
segment.target: You can interact with the camera at a low level, and capture audio with classes in Windows.Media.Capture such as the MediaCapture API.

segment.source: Playing audio and video files.
segment.target: Playing audio and video files.

segment.source: The MediaPlayer and AudioManager classes are used to play audio and video files.
segment.target: The MediaPlayer and AudioManager classes are used to play audio and video files.

segment.source: The AVKit framework, AVAudioPlayer, and Media Player Framework are used to play audio and video files.
segment.target: The AVKit framework, AVAudioPlayer, and Media Player Framework are used to play audio and video files.

segment.source: You can use the MediaSource class, MediaElement, and MediaPlayer classes to play back audio and video from sources such as local and remote files.
segment.target: You can use the MediaSource class, MediaElement, and MediaPlayer classes to play back audio and video from sources such as local and remote files.

segment.target: Media playback with MediaSource

segment.source: Editing media.
segment.target: Editing media.

segment.source: Composing new media files from existing recordings and applying special effects.
segment.target: Composing new media files from existing recordings and applying special effects.

segment.source: Low level classes such as MediaCodec, MediaMuxer, and android.media.effect can be used for content editing.
segment.target: Low level classes such as MediaCodec, MediaMuxer, and android.media.effect can be used for content editing.

segment.source: Classes in the AV Foundation framework such as AVMutableComposition, AVMutableVideoComposition, and AVMutableAudioMix can be used for content editing.
segment.target: Classes in the AV Foundation framework such as AVMutableComposition, AVMutableVideoComposition, and AVMutableAudioMix can be used for content editing.

segment.source: You can use the Windows.Media.Editing APIs such as MediaComposition and MediaClip to create media compositions from audio and video files.
segment.target: You can use the Windows.Media.Editing APIs such as MediaComposition and MediaClip to create media compositions from audio and video files.

segment.source: You are able to add video and image overlays, combine video clips, add background audio, and apply audio and video effects.
segment.target: You are able to add video and image overlays, combine video clips, add background audio, and apply audio and video effects.

segment.source: Detect device movement, position and environmental properties.

segment.source: The sensor framework is used to access hardware and software sensors with classes such as SensorManager and SensorEvent.
segment.target: The sensor framework is used to access hardware and software sensors with classes such as SensorManager and SensorEvent.

segment.source: The Core Motion framework is used to access raw and processed sensor data.
segment.target: The Core Motion framework is used to access raw and processed sensor data.

segment.source: You can use classes in Windows.Devices.Sensors to access sensor readings and events triggered when new reading data is received from the sensor.
segment.target: You can use classes in Windows.Devices.Sensors to access sensor readings and events triggered when new reading data is received from the sensor.

segment.source: Location.
segment.target: Location.

segment.source: Finding the device's current location and tracking changes.
segment.target: Finding the device's current location and tracking changes.

segment.source: The Google Play services location APIs provide high-level access to the last known location with the fused location provider using the getLastLocation and requestLocationUpdates methods.
segment.target: The Google Play services location APIs provide high-level access to the last known location with the fused location provider using the getLastLocation and requestLocationUpdates methods.

segment.source: Low-level access is provided in the Android libraries with the LocationManager.
segment.target: Low-level access is provided in the Android libraries with the LocationManager.

segment.source: The Core Location CLLocationManager class is used to monitor a device's location, with startUpdatingLocation for the standard location service and startMonitoringSignificantLocationChanges for the significant-change location service.
segment.target: The Core Location CLLocationManager class is used to monitor a device's location, with startUpdatingLocation for the standard location service and startMonitoringSignificantLocationChanges for the significant-change location service.

segment.source: You can track device location with classes in Windows.Devices.Geolocation.
segment.target: You can track device location with classes in Windows.Devices.Geolocation.

segment.source: Use Geolocator.GetGeopositionAsync for a one-time reading.
segment.target: Use Geolocator.GetGeopositionAsync for a one-time reading.

segment.source: Use Geolocator.PositionChanged to obtain the location regularly using a timer, or be informed when the location has changed.
segment.target: Use Geolocator.PositionChanged to obtain the location regularly using a timer, or be informed when the location has changed.

segment.source: Get the user's location
segment.target: Get the user's location

segment.source: Displaying maps.
segment.target: Displaying maps.

segment.source: Displaying an interactive built-in map and adding points of interest.
segment.target: Displaying an interactive built-in map and adding points of interest.

segment.source: The GoogleMap, MapFragment, and MapView classes within the Google Maps Android API allow maps to be embedded in apps.
segment.target: The GoogleMap, MapFragment, and MapView classes within the Google Maps Android API allow maps to be embedded in apps.

segment.source: Points of interest can be displayed using markers and the customizable Marker class.
segment.target: Points of interest can be displayed using markers and the customizable Marker class.

segment.source: Maps are embedded into iOS apps with the MKMapView class in the MapKit framework.
segment.target: Maps are embedded into iOS apps with the MKMapView class in the MapKit framework.

segment.source: Annotations can be added to apps to display points of interest using object classes such as MKPointAnnotation and view classes such as MKPinAnnotationView.
segment.target: Annotations can be added to apps to display points of interest using object classes such as MKPointAnnotation and view classes such as MKPinAnnotationView.

segment.source: You can embed maps in your apps using the built-in MapControl XAML control which provides 2D, 3D, and streetside views.
segment.target: You can embed maps in your apps using the built-in MapControl XAML control which provides 2D, 3D, and streetside views.

segment.source: You can add points of interest with a pushpin, image, or shape using classes such as MapIcon, MapPolygon and MapPolyline.
segment.target: You can add points of interest with a pushpin, image, or shape using classes such as MapIcon, MapPolygon and MapPolyline.

segment.target: Display maps with 2D, 3D, and Streetside views

segment.source: Geofencing.
segment.target: Geofencing.

segment.source: Monitor the entering and leaving of a particular geographic region.
segment.target: Monitor the entering and leaving of a particular geographic region.

segment.source: Geofences are monitored using the Location Services in the Google Play Services SDK.
segment.target: Geofences are monitored using the Location Services in the Google Play Services SDK.

segment.source: Regions are monitored with the CLCircularRegion class and registered with the CLLocationManager.startMonitoringForRegion:.
segment.target: Regions are monitored with the CLCircularRegion class and registered with the CLLocationManager.startMonitoringForRegion:.

segment.source: You can create a geofence with the Geofence class and define your monitored states such as entering or leaving a region.
segment.target: You can create a geofence with the Geofence class and define your monitored states such as entering or leaving a region.

segment.source: Handle geofence events in the foreground with the GeofenceMonitor class, and in the background with the LocationTrigger background class.
segment.target: Handle geofence events in the foreground with the GeofenceMonitor class, and in the background with the LocationTrigger background class.

segment.source: Geocoding and reverse geocoding.
segment.target: Geocoding and reverse geocoding.

segment.source: Converting addresses to geographic locations (geocoding) and converting geographic locations to addresses (reverse geocoding).
segment.target: Converting addresses to geographic locations (geocoding) and converting geographic locations to addresses (reverse geocoding).

segment.source: The Geocoder class is used for geocoding and reverse geocoding.
segment.target: The Geocoder class is used for geocoding and reverse geocoding.

segment.source: The CLGeocoder class is used for geocoding.
segment.target: The CLGeocoder class is used for geocoding.

segment.source: You can perform geocoding using the MapLocationFinder class in Windows.Services.Maps.
segment.target: You can perform geocoding using the MapLocationFinder class in Windows.Services.Maps.

segment.source: You use FindLocationsAsync for geocoding and FindLocationsAtAsync for reverse geocoding.
segment.target: You use FindLocationsAsync for geocoding and FindLocationsAtAsync for reverse geocoding.

segment.target: Routes and directions.

segment.source: Providing routes, distances, and directions between two geographical locations.
segment.target: Providing routes, distances, and directions between two geographical locations.

segment.source: Google provides the web service Google Maps Directions API which can be used on Android although no SDK is provided.
segment.target: Google provides the web service Google Maps Directions API which can be used on Android although no SDK is provided.

segment.source: Map Kit provides the MKDirections API which can be used to fetch information about a route and directions.
segment.target: Map Kit provides the MKDirections API which can be used to fetch information about a route and directions.

segment.source: You can request a walking or driving route with the MapRouteFinder class in Windows.Services.Maps.
segment.target: You can request a walking or driving route with the MapRouteFinder class in Windows.Services.Maps.

segment.source: Routes are returned as a MapRoute instance which can be easily shown on a MapControl.
segment.target: Routes are returned as a MapRoute instance which can be easily shown on a MapControl.

segment.source: Directions are returned inside the MapRouteManeuver object.
segment.target: Directions are returned inside the MapRouteManeuver object.

segment.source: Launching another app, and optionally sharing data such as links, text, photos, videos, and files.
segment.target: Launching another app, and optionally sharing data such as links, text, photos, videos, and files.

segment.source: An implicit intent is used to launch another app, by defining an action and optional data in an Intent and calling it with startActivityForResult.
segment.target: An implicit intent is used to launch another app, by defining an action and optional data in an Intent and calling it with startActivityForResult.

segment.source: App extensions can be used to provide access to app data to another app.
segment.target: App extensions can be used to provide access to app data to another app.

segment.source: URL schemes enable a URL to be passed to another app.
segment.target: URL schemes enable a URL to be passed to another app.

segment.source: You can launch another app which has registered for a URI with Launcher.LaunchUriAsync, or Launcher.LaunchUriForResultsAsync to launch for results and get data back from the launched app.
segment.target: You can launch another app which has registered for a URI with Launcher.LaunchUriAsync, or Launcher.LaunchUriForResultsAsync to launch for results and get data back from the launched app.

segment.source: You can use Launcher.LaunchFileAsync to pass a file to another app to handle.
segment.target: You can use Launcher.LaunchFileAsync to pass a file to another app to handle.

segment.source: You can use a share contract to easily share data between apps.

segment.source: Allow your app to respond to a request from another app.
segment.target: Allow your app to respond to a request from another app.

segment.source: Apps register an intent handling activity with an intent filter to respond to an implicit intent from another app.
segment.target: Apps register an intent handling activity with an intent filter to respond to an implicit intent from another app.

segment.source: Packaging an app extension enables data to be shared with other apps.
segment.target: Packaging an app extension enables data to be shared with other apps.

segment.source: Apps can register a custom URL scheme using the CFBundleURLTypes key in Info.plist.
segment.target: Apps can register a custom URL scheme using the CFBundleURLTypes key in Info.plist.

segment.source: You can register your app to be the default handler for a URI scheme name by registering a protocol in the package manifest and updating the Application.OnActivated event handler, optionally returning results.
segment.target: You can register your app to be the default handler for a URI scheme name by registering a protocol in the package manifest and updating the Application.OnActivated event handler, optionally returning results.

segment.source: In the same way you can register your app to be the default handler for certain file types by adding a declaration in the package manifest and handling the Application.OnFileActivated event.
segment.target: In the same way you can register your app to be the default handler for certain file types by adding a declaration in the package manifest and handling the Application.OnFileActivated event.

segment.source: You can handle share contract requests by registering your app as a share target in the manifest and handling the Application.OnShareTargetActivated event.
segment.target: You can handle share contract requests by registering your app as a share target in the manifest and handling the Application.OnShareTargetActivated event.

segment.source: Copy and pasting text and other content between apps.
segment.target: Copy and pasting text and other content between apps.

segment.source: The clipboard framework can be used to implement copy and paste with the ClipboardManager and ClipData classes.
segment.target: The clipboard framework can be used to implement copy and paste with the ClipboardManager and ClipData classes.

segment.source: The UIPasteboard, UIMenuController, and UIResponderStandardEditActions can be used to implement copy and paste.
segment.target: The UIPasteboard, UIMenuController, and UIResponderStandardEditActions can be used to implement copy and paste.

segment.source: Many default XAML controls already support copy and paste.
segment.target: Many default XAML controls already support copy and paste.

segment.source: You can implement copy and paste yourself using the DataPackage and Clipboard classes in Windows.ApplicationModel.DataTransfer.
segment.target: You can implement copy and paste yourself using the DataPackage and Clipboard classes in Windows.ApplicationModel.DataTransfer.

segment.source: Drag and drop.
segment.target: Drag and drop.

segment.source: Dragging and dropping content between apps.
segment.target: Dragging and dropping content between apps.

segment.source: Drag and drop can be implemented within a single application by using the Android drag/drop framework.
segment.target: Drag and drop can be implemented within a single application by using the Android drag/drop framework.

segment.source: No high-level drag and drop APIs are provided by iOS.
segment.target: No high-level drag and drop APIs are provided by iOS.

segment.source: You can implement dragging and dropping in your app to enable app-to-app, desktop-to-app, and app-to-desktop drag and drop capabilities.
segment.target: You can implement dragging and dropping in your app to enable app-to-app, desktop-to-app, and app-to-desktop drag and drop capabilities.

segment.source: You implement drag and drop support in the UIElement class with the AllowDrop, and CanDrag properties, and the DragOver, and Drop events.
segment.target: You implement drag and drop support in the UIElement class with the AllowDrop, and CanDrag properties, and the DragOver, and Drop events.

segment.source: Software design patterns.
segment.target: Software design patterns.

segment.source: Recommended or well-used patterns for the platform.
segment.target: Recommended or well-used patterns for the platform.

segment.source: No formal pattern has been recommended or provided for Android development, although the beta Data Binding Framework may enable more widespread use of the Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern.
segment.target: No formal pattern has been recommended or provided for Android development, although the beta Data Binding Framework may enable more widespread use of the Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern.

segment.source: A number of third party articles and frameworks recommend the Model-View-Presenter (MVP) and MVVM approaches.
segment.target: A number of third party articles and frameworks recommend the Model-View-Presenter (MVP) and MVVM approaches.

segment.source: Model-View-Controller (MVC) is a common pattern used with iOS and is integrated into the platform.
segment.target: Model-View-Controller (MVC) is a common pattern used with iOS and is integrated into the platform.

segment.source: You are not limited towards a specific pattern when building for UWP.
segment.target: You are not limited towards a specific pattern when building for UWP.

segment.source: You can use the built-in data binding pattern to ensure clean separation of data concerns and UI concerns, and avoid having to code up UI event handlers which then update property values.
segment.target: You can use the built-in data binding pattern to ensure clean separation of data concerns and UI concerns, and avoid having to code up UI event handlers which then update property values.

segment.source: You can extend data binding to follow the Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern, either by making use of third-party MVVM libraries such as MVVM Light Toolkit, or rolling your own and keeping logic out of code-behind.
segment.target: You can extend data binding to follow the Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern, either by making use of third-party MVVM libraries such as MVVM Light Toolkit, or rolling your own and keeping logic out of code-behind.
